newsitem.title: USA: Harrah's sees mid-97 Atlantic City rebound.
newsitem.headline: Harrah's sees mid-97 Atlantic City rebound.

text.p: Harrah's Entertainment Inc expects profits from its Atlantic City gaming operations to begin to rebound in mid-1997, president and chief executive Philip Satre said.

"In 1995, we saw a lot of new supply come on and now we're seeing the market struggling to absorb that supply," Satre told the Montgomery Securities Investment Conference. "We expect to begin rebuilding profit in Atlantic City in mid-1997."

Satre said that, while rapid expansion of gaming capacity has in the past been associated with periods of soft profits, over time "additional rooms have proven to build profit and will continue to do so in the future."
Harrah's expects next year to complete an $80 million casino and room expansion of Harrah's Atlantic City.

Satre also told the conference that the company recently completed a study projecting U.S. casino revenues would grow 50 percent over the next five years, under the most conservative scenario. Under the most aggressive scenario, he said revenues could double over the same time period.
The different scenarios used in the forecast were based on different numbers of new jurisdictions to pass gambling legislation, which, Satre said, was "impossible to predict."
